title: Non-Sexual Intimacy
description: Explore the forms of closeness that don't involve sex but strengthen your bond.

questions.text: The non-sexual physical connection I value most is...
choices: Physical closeness while doing other things

therapeutic.rationale: Non-sexual touch preferences vary. Cuddlers want extended closeness; casual-touchers want constant low-level connection; hug-lovers want meaningful moments; proximity-seekers want parallel togetherness. All build intimacy differently.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different preferences mean giving in different ways. The cuddler may not realize casual touches mean love; the casual-toucher may not realize their partner needs more extended closeness.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared non-sexual touch preference creates natural physical connection patterns.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What non-sexual physical touch do you most value? Are you getting enough of it?

questions.text: The role of non-sexual intimacy in our relationship should be...
choices: Important—but I don't need a lot

therapeutic.rationale: Views on non-sexual intimacy's role vary. Central-viewers build everything on it; frequent-wanters need regular doses; important-but-less types need less; natural-flow types don't want to plan it. Alignment here prevents feeling over or under-connected.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs require adjustment. The central-viewer may feel neglected by the important-but-less partner; the important-but-less partner may feel smothered. Find your balance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared view on non-sexual intimacy's role aligns your expectations.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How important is non-sexual intimacy to you? What role does it play in feeling connected?

questions.text: I feel close to my partner through non-physical intimacy when we...

therapeutic.rationale: Emotional intimacy pathways vary. Deep-talkers connect through conversation; silence-sharers connect through presence; laughter-lovers connect through joy; support-sharers connect through hardship. Knowing your partner's pathway helps you walk it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different pathways can all be traveled. The deep-talker may not realize laughter counts as intimacy for their partner; the silence-sharer may not realize their partner needs more words.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared emotional intimacy pathway makes connection feel natural and aligned.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What creates emotional intimacy for you outside of physical touch? How do you feel closest?

questions.text: When we haven't had non-sexual closeness in a while, I tend to...
choices: Not notice unless it's been a long time
Feel it affecting other parts of our relationship

therapeutic.rationale: Responses to intimacy gaps reveal attachment needs. Disconnection-feelers need regular closeness; not-noticers are lower-need; initiators take action; whole-relationship feelers see ripple effects. Understanding your partner's response helps during busy times.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The disconnection-feeler may suffer silently while the not-noticer doesn't realize. Check in during busy seasons.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared response to intimacy gaps means you'll notice and address disconnection similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when non-sexual intimacy has been lacking? What do you need?

questions.text: The daily ritual of connection I'd most value is...
choices: Time set aside just to be together
Checking in about each other's lives

therapeutic.rationale: Connection rituals ground relationships. Greeting-valuing types want transitions honored; together-time types want dedicated moments; touch-throughout types want constant contact; check-in types want emotional tracking. Rituals create predictable connection.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different rituals can coexist. You can have meaningful greetings AND dedicated time AND physical affection. Build rituals that serve both of you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ritual preference makes building daily connection patterns easy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What daily connection ritual would make you feel most loved and connected?
